Type aliases

Alpha

Alpha: number[]
brief

Alpha vector which can be of any size. This is essentially a renaming in order to match this publication

AlphaParameters

AlphaParameters: { mapping?: alphaMapping; max: number[]; min: number[] }
brief

Parameters for defining Alpha, i.e., the min/max of each value as well as an optional [[AlphaMapping]] which allows to convert a user-defined parameter space to the global one. For stochastic smulation, parameters will be sampled in these ranges.

example
// First parameters is theta in [0°, 180°]
// Second parameter is stress ratio in [0, 3]
const parameters = { 
    mapping: new SimpleAndersonMapping,
    min: [  0, 0],
    max: [180, 3]
}

Type declaration

  • Optional mapping?: alphaMapping
  • max: number[]
  • min: number[]

Data

Data: { calculus: string[]; cost: CostFunction; dataframe: DataFrame; measure: string; weight: number }

Interface for a data that comprises the measurement (name of in the dataframe), the associated cost function, the name of the series in order to perform the superposition, and the dataframe itself

Type declaration

  • calculus: string[]

    The names of the series to perform superpposition (must be in the dataframe)

  • cost: CostFunction

    The associated cost function

  • dataframe: DataFrame

    The dataframe supporting all series (measures and calculus)

  • measure: string

    The name of the serie for the measures (must be in the dataframe)

  • weight: number

    The weight of this data

InversionModel

InversionModel: { alphaParameters: AlphaParameters; data: Data[] }
brief

Parameters for the inversion, which are the measured and the calculated data along with their associated cost function and weight. The AlphaParameters has to be provided as well with the number of iterations for the inversion algorithm.

Type declaration

  • alphaParameters: AlphaParameters

    The parameter space to use with the mapping if necessary

  • data: Data[]

    All the provided Data to perform the inversion

InversionResult

InversionResult: { alpha: number[]; cost: number; user: number[] }
brief

The inversion solution

Type declaration

  • alpha: number[]

    The inverted Alpha parameters

  • cost: number

    The best cost from inversion

  • user: number[]

    The corresponding inverted user parameters (inverse mapping)

Geology Functions

costConjugate

  • costConjugate(n: ASerie, stress: ASerie, w?: number, fric?: number, projected?: boolean): Serie<any>

  • Cost for conjugate planes

    Parameters

    • n: ASerie

      The normal to the observed fracture

    • stress: ASerie

      The computed symetric stress tensor

    • w: number = 1

      Weight with default value 1

    • fric: number = 60

      Friction angle in degrees with default value 60

    • projected: boolean = false

      If we have to project on a plane with default value false

      Relation between a shear fracture and the three principales stresses

    Returns Serie<any>

costJoint

  • costJoint(n: ASerie, stress: ASerie, w?: number): ASerie

  • Cost for joint fractures

    Parameters

    • n: ASerie

      The normal to the observed fracture

    • stress: ASerie

      The computed symetric stress tensor

    • w: number = 1

      Weight with default value 1

      Relation between a joint and the three principales stresses

    Returns ASerie

costStriation

  • costStriation(obs: ASerie, calc: ASerie, w?: number): ASerie

  • Cost for a fault striation

    note

    Make sure that the coordinate system of the measure is the same as the computed slip vector.

    note

    You can use the class [[TriangleCS]].

    Parameters

    • obs: ASerie

      The observed striation vector in the triangle coordinate system

    • calc: ASerie

      The computed displacement in the triangle coordinate system

    • w: number = 1

      Weight with default value 1

    Returns ASerie

costStylolite

  • costStylolite(n: ASerie, stress: ASerie, w?: number): ASerie

  • Cost for stylolite fractures

    Parameters

    • n: ASerie

      The normal to the observed fracture

    • stress: ASerie

      The computed symetric stress tensor

    • w: number = 1

      Weight with default value 1

      Relation between a stylolite and the three principales stresses

    Returns ASerie

Geophysics Functions

costGps

  • costGps(obs: ASerie, calc: ASerie, w?: number): ASerie

  • Cost for a Gps measure (at one point)

    Parameters

    • obs: ASerie

      The measure gps vector

    • calc: ASerie
    • w: number = 1

      Weight with default value 1

      Equation for a GPS data. Upper sripts m and c stand for measured and computed, respectively

    Returns ASerie

costInsar

  • costInsar(obs: ASerie, calc: ASerie, w?: number): ASerie

  • Cost for an Insar measure (at one point)

    see

    generateInsar

    Equation for an Insar data. Upper sripts m and c stand for measured and computed, respectively. Computed Insar is using the function generateInsar, which makes use of the satellite line of sight.

    Parameters

    • obs: ASerie

      The Insar measure along the satellite line of sight

    • calc: ASerie
    • w: number = 1

      Weight with default value 1

    Returns ASerie

costVerticalGps

  • costVerticalGps(obs: ASerie, calc: ASerie, w?: number): ASerie

  • Cost for a vertical Gps measure (at one point)

    example
    import * as geom   from '@youwol/geometry'
import * as geophy from '@youwol/geophysics'

const displ   = computDispl() // user function
const horizon = [...] // set of 3D points in a flat array

// Get the fitting plane for the horizon
const plane = geom.fittingPlane(horizon)

// and compute the cost
let cost = 0
for (let i=0; i<horizon.length; i+=3) {
    const p = [horizon[i], horizon[i+1], horizon[i+2]]
    const d = geom.distanceFromPointToPlane(p, plane)
    cost += geophy.costVerticalGps(p, d, 1)
}
cost /= horizon.length/3
    Equation for a vertical GPS data.

    Parameters

    • obs: ASerie

      The measure vertical gps value

    • calc: ASerie
    • w: number = 1

      Weight with default value 1

    Returns ASerie

generateInsar

  • generateInsar(displ: ASerie, satellite: Vector3): ASerie

  • Given a displacement field and a satellite line of sight, compute the corresponding Insar data.

    see

    costInsar

    example

    In the following example, the displacement field displ is computed using numerically, and the measuredInsar are the measures (observations). The size of displ is three times the size of insar.

    const computedInsar = generateInsar(displ, [0.01, -0.1, -0.9856])
const measuredInsar = [...]

// Let use a loop instead of the Array.redure method
const cost = 0
for (let i=0; i<computedInsar.length; ++i) {
    cost += costInsar(computedInsar[i], measuredInsar[i])
}
cost /= computedInsar.length

    Parameters

    • displ: ASerie

      The displacement field as a flat array

    • satellite: Vector3

      The satellite line of sight

    Returns ASerie

Inversion Functions

Const monteCarlo

  • monteCarlo(params: InversionModel, n: number): InversionResult
  • brief

    A monte-carlo algorithm to perform an inversion.

    Parameters

    • params: InversionModel

      The inversion parameters

    • n: number

    Returns InversionResult

Other Functions

Const cost

  • cost(data: Data | Data[], alpha: Alpha): number

  • Compute the associated cost to alpha given an array of Data.

    note

    When data is an array, returns the weighted cost. Otherwise, returns the cost (not multipled by the weight of the data).

    Parameters

    • data: Data | Data[]
    • alpha: Alpha

    Returns number

Const defaultMapping

  • defaultMapping(alpha: Alpha): Alpha

  • A default mapping for any Alpha. Basically it return the same alpha.

    see

    [[AlphaMapping]]

    Parameters

    • alpha: Alpha

    Returns Alpha

Const gradientPressureMapping

  • gradientPressureMapping(alpha: Alpha): Alpha

  • Transform the user-parameter-space [theta, Rh, RH, rockDensity, cavityDensity, shift1, shift2...] to the global one [Sxx, Sxy, Syy, Szz, density, shift1, shift2...], where theta is the orientation of the maximum principal horizontal stress according to the north, clock-wize and in [0..180], Rh is the ratio of Sigma_h/Sigma_v, RH is the ratio of Sigma_H/Sigma_v, and the shifts are the pressure shift of the cavity at z=0.

    Note that this regional stress and the pressure use the gradient and that you can provide as many shift pressures as necessary (as long as the number of linearly independent simulations are computed)

    see

    [[Mapping]]

    example
    // provide 2 pressure shifts
const alpha = GradientPressureMapping([45, 0.1, 0.2, 2300, 2200, -1e6, -1e7])

    Parameters

    • alpha: Alpha

      The user-define parameter space

    Returns Alpha

    [Sxx, Sxy, Syy, Szz, cavityDensity, shift1, shift2...]

Const simpleAndersonMapping

  • simpleAndersonMapping(alpha: Alpha): Alpha
  • brief

    Convert the regional Andersonian stress (theta, R) into the global CSys [xx, xy, yy]. Basically, this fonction convert a non-linear space into a linear one in order to be used by the superposition. This regional stress is not defined with gradient.

    see

    [[AlphaMapping]]

    see

    publication
    Maerten, F., Madden, E. H., Pollard, D. D., & Maerten, L. (2016). Incorporating fault mechanics into inversions of aftershock data for the regional remote stress, with application to the 1992 Landers, California earthquake. Tectonophysics, 674, 52-64.

    Parameters

    • alpha: Alpha

      In the form [theta, R], with theta the angle in degrees of the maximum principal horizontal stress according to the north and clock wize and defined in the range [0..180], R the extended stress ratio in [0..3].

      For instance:

      • if R ∈ [0..1], then it is a normal fault regime
      • if R ∈ [1..2], then it is a strike slip fault regime
      • if R ∈ [2..3], then it is a reverse fault regime

    Returns Alpha
